secret_rule: Only items that are typically associated with famous landmarks around the world can be brought to the picnic.

conversation.content: To start, here are some examples of items you can bring: "Eiffel Tower keychain" and "Statue of Liberty snow globe".
Can I bring a "Taj Mahal replica" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Taj Mahal replica."
I'll make a new guess. Can I bring a "Colosseum model" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Colosseum model."
I'll make a new guess. Can I bring a "Great Wall of China puzzle" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Great Wall of China puzzle."
Player: Can I bring a "Pyramids of Giza sculpture" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Pyramids of Giza sculpture."

Based on the examples provided by the game master and the successful guesses, it seems that the rule might involve bringing models or replicas of famous landmarks or monuments to the game.

I will make a new guess: Can I bring a "Sydney Opera House miniature" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Sydney Opera House miniature."
I'll make a new guess: Can I bring a "Big Ben clock tower model" to the game?
Yes, you can bring a "Big Ben clock tower model."

Based on the examples provided by the game master and the successful guesses you made, the rule seems to involve bringing items that are models, replicas, or miniatures of well-known landmarks or monuments from around the world. Each item mentioned represents an iconic architectural structure or cultural symbol of a specific place. Therefore, the rule likely requires that items represent renowned landmarks or monuments.
Correct! The rule is: Only items that are typically associated with famous landmarks around the world can be brought to the picnic.
